steps.title: Put salted water in a pot.
steps.content: Put salted water in a pot. Put a few inches of water in the bottom of a large pot. You only need enough to create steam to wilt your arugula. To give your arugula a bit more flavor, add a pinch of salt to the pot of water. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Heat the water to boiling.
steps.content: Heat the water to boiling. Place the pot of salted water on a stovetop burner and heat it to boiling. Then, turn the heat down so the water bubbles gently. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Place arugula in a vegetable steamer over the boiling water.
steps.content: Place arugula in a vegetable steamer over the boiling water. If you don’t have a steamer, you can rest a metal colander or strainer inside the pot, making sure the boiling water doesn’t touch it. Use as much arugula as you think you will need. Cover the pot to trap the steam inside. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wilt the arugula for 2-3 minutes over the water.
steps.content: Wilt the arugula for 2-3 minutes over the water. Allow the arugula to steam for a few minutes, or until wilted to your liking. Then, carefully remove the steamer from the pot of water and serve the arugula. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Heat chicken broth and spices on the stovetop.
steps.content: Heat chicken broth and spices on the stovetop. Put ¼ cup (60 mL) of chicken broth (you may choose a reduced-sodium variety, if desired), ⅛ teaspoon (0.5 mL) of onion powder, ⅛ teaspoon (0.5 mL) of garlic powder, and a dash of pepper into a frying pan. Stir to combine, and heat the mixture until it boils. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Add arugula to the pan.
steps.content: Add arugula to the pan. Mix in 5 ounces (150 g) of washed and trimmed fresh arugula. Make sure the arugula is evenly coated in the broth and spice mixture by using tongs to toss the greens in the liquid. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Stir occasionally and let it wilt.
steps.content: Stir occasionally and let it wilt. Keep the pan on the burner for another minute or two to allow the arugula leaves to wilt. If needed, add another splash of chicken broth to keep the arugula wet. Stir the mixture occasionally. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the pan from heat and serve the dish.
steps.content: Remove the pan from heat and serve the dish. All you need to do now is turn off your burner, remove the pan from heat, and serve the arugula. You can have it as a side dish with a meal, put it on mashed potatoes, or use it as a salad topping. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Melt butter in a pan.
steps.content: Melt butter in a pan. Put a medium saucepan on a stovetop burner set to medium heat. Add 4 tablespoons (½ of a stick or 57 g) of unsalted butter and allow it to melt. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Add onion and thyme and cook them for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Add onion and thyme and cook them for 5 minutes. Add ½ of a chopped onion and 3 sprigs of thyme, with the leaves removed. Stir the mixture and cook it about 5 minutes, or until the onions are translucent. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Add potatoes to the pan and cook them for 2 minutes.
steps.content: Add potatoes to the pan and cook them for 2 minutes. Wash and peel 1 small Yukon Gold potato (or ½ of a russet potato), then cut it into 1-inch (2.54-cm) pieces. Stir the potato pieces into the pan and cook them for about 2 minutes, or until the potatoes look chalky. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Mix in broth and cook the potatoes another 8-10 minutes.
steps.content: Mix in broth and cook the potatoes another 8-10 minutes. Pour 4 cups (1 L) of chicken broth (you can use a low-sodium broth if you wish) into the pan. Stir to combine the ingredients, then bring the mixture to a boil. Cook it for 8-10 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Add arugula, peas, and sugar, then remove the pan from heat.
steps.content: Add arugula, peas, and sugar, then remove the pan from heat. Add 4 cups (1 L) of chopped, wilted arugula, 1 ½ cups (343 mL) of frozen peas, thawed, and 1 teaspoon (5.0 mL) of sugar to the pan. Mix the new ingredients thoroughly into the broth and potato mixture. Remove the pan from heat. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the mixture to sit for 10 minutes, then puree it.
steps.content: Allow the mixture to sit for 10 minutes, then puree it. Let the heat of the other ingredients soften the arugula for around 10 minutes. Then, pour the mixture into a blender and run it until all the ingredients are smoothly blended. You can season the soup with salt at this point, if desired. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Top the soup with crème fraîche and herbs, then serve it.
steps.content: Top the soup with crème fraîche and herbs, then serve it. Pour the soup into serving bowls. Put a dollop of crème fraîche on top of each portion of soup, then add chopped herbs (like tarragon, mint, parsley, or chives), and serve your soup. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Preheat your oven then pound the chicken cutlets thinly.
steps.content: Preheat your oven then pound the chicken cutlets thinly. Preheat your oven to 425° F (218° C). To serve four people, use four chicken breasts (totalling 1.5 lbs or 0.68 kg). Place plastic wrap over the chicken breast cutlets. Pound the meat with the smooth side meat tenderizer until you have a thin, even layer. [16] X Research source You could substitute chicken for flank steak in this recipe, as well!

steps.title: Arrange goat cheese and arugula on the chicken.
steps.content: Arrange goat cheese and arugula on the chicken. First, add salt and pepper to your meat to season it. Then, lay the chicken flat and layer arugula and chunks of goat cheese in the middle of the meat. [17] X Research source For four people, 4 oz. (115 g) of trimmed and washed arugula and 4 oz. (115 g) of soft goat cheese, broken into pieces, should suffice.

steps.title: Roll up the chicken cutlets.
steps.content: Roll up the chicken cutlets. Begin with the narrowest end and roll the meat up into a pinwheel, or “roulade.” Wrap the meat with kitchen twine or secure it with toothpicks so they don’t unroll. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Brown the roulades.
steps.content: Brown the roulades. Put 1-2 tablespoons (15-30 mL) of butter or olive oil in a large non-stick, oven-proof skillet. Heat the butter or oil over medium heat, then add the roulades. Brown them on all sides. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Put the skillet in the oven.
steps.content: Put the skillet in the oven. Place the skillet in your preheated oven and cook for about 10-12 minutes, or until chicken is cooked through to 165° F (74 ° C). Carefully remove the pan from the oven using a pot holder. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the chicken with foil and allow it to rest.
steps.content: Cover the chicken with foil and allow it to rest. Place aluminum foil over the skillet and seal it semi-tightly. Allow the dish to rest for 5 minutes, then remove the foil and the toothpicks or twine. Cut the roulades into round slices and serve the dish. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Finished.
steps.content: Finished.
